text: Little bit of oversharing for a youtube comment, but due to an issue with repressed memories and being drugged by an abusive parent until i was 13ish, I realized that despite remembering this as one of the most enjoyable games I ever played, I have almost zero memory of it after the first hour (along with most things from my life before high school), no matter how hard I try to remember. I'm not looking for pity, I'm long past all of that, being 20 surrounded by great friends and in an amazing several year long relationship with someone I really want to marry. The way I see it, I have a privilege that many before me and i'm sure some reading this comment wish they could have, I get to play Chrono Trigger for the first time again. And I can not wait.

text: Usually games/movies with time travel focus on the future being more interesting and how events today influence that future outcome. This game reverses that and makes it so the past is the most interesting and mysterious part of the world, and the things that happen in that time period shape the present reality. This game and especially the music from 12,000 BC era captures the mystique perfectly. It feels like the height of advancement, and in many ways it is--the Gurus shape the world by employing their understanding in concrete ways, but are influenced and forced to work under a selfish and vain leader, oddly freed from her by Lavos own action to split them up in time. Even though all 3 are separated, they still use their knowledge and abilities to do things that together, unbeknownst to them all, work together to save the world, without them being certain of the outcome. Courage and hope displayed in spite of the overwhelming calamity they witnessed at the hands of Lavos. While I don't know if this is a reference to the trinity of God, I do find it interesting that all 3 of them seem to be of one mind and action in many ways, made manifest in different forms, and that their assistance to the heroes is selfless. Also interesting is that the seemingly victorious action of the enemy itself leads paradoxically to it's defeat. (Lavos freeing the gurus from the influence and command of Queen Zeal by throwing them into different parts of time)

text:
...This tune gives me some serious Nausica√§ of the Valley of the Wind vibes, to the point where I have to wonder why I never noticed before.

The intro sounds like kind of a mix of multiple BG tracks connected to the Sea of Corruption. After that, the tune basically sounds like the melody 1 minute into the  track "The Princess Who Loves Insects".

I do know for a fact that Square took some inspiration from Nausica√§ back in the 8-bit days, such as the chocobo basically being a horse-claw, but I never thought there might be musical inspiration as well, a good eleven years later.
author: JediMB

text:
Even after all these tears, I still can't find any words fitting enough to describe how much I love Chrono Trigger
I happened to play it for the first time around 2010, I was like 11 at the time
And from the first second of the game I knew that I would never find a better or even matching game (that was before I discovered FFVI, which I equally rank with CT as my favorite game ever)

How can such a wonderful thing exist? I feel so blessed that I had the chance to finish it, it feels like a heaven sent gift sometimes...

And there I come to Zeal... And stay on the world map for hours without touching my controller, just listening to that masterpiece we got here...
Even now when I listen to it again while closing my eyes I forget about all my life issues and let myself go away with the music

I unfortunetaly don't have as much time as I did when I was in middle school so I can't play it anymore bc my studies are way too much time-consuming but it will always have a special significance in my heart, even when I'm old I'll make sure thay my kids and grandkids get to play that game, whether they like it or not, at least I will have shared my passion for it

To this day, I have played a lot of games since I stumbled upon CT but no one was as good as it is, and whenever I have to talk about my videogames tastes I first mention Chrono Trigger

May Zeal live forever in our hearts!

author: Daniel Ramirez

text:
Woho, I just finished Chrono Trigger for the first time! Here is my personal opinions of the game. 

I have always loved the snes era so I thought I had missed out on something when I had not played Chrono Trigger. It turns out I got mixed feelings about the game though.

First of all did I not like the gameplay. I prefer regular turn based over this, like in earthbound or golden sun (man I love those two games). I am quite surprised over me not liking the gameplay since I usually like it when you mix things up in jrpgs (like in xenoblade or in earthbound where your life scrolls down instead of drops instantly after an attack), however in chrono trigger the gameplay was just stressful, which is the opposite of what I want from a jrpg!

And for the second, I did not like the fantasy setting the game was in. It just felt alot like dungeons and dragons or something similar. I am not a fan of fantasy overall, and I do not like dragon ball either so that does not make the setting any better. :(

These two complaints are probably the only reason why I have so many mixed feelings for the game. Unfortunately I did not like two very important aspects of the game. :( 

That being said, this is not a bad game! It is just not my game.. unfortunately.

However, I must say I found myself amazed over 12000 bc. That was so awesome! The snowstorm under the clouds, and then you ascend over the clouds and this music starts playing and you see that you are in a highly advanced city shivers. I think 12000 bc was the best part of the game, and probably the part of the game I found most memorable! Easily one of the most beautiful places in video game history!
author: YolmzWelra

text: That's because you started while knowing everyone says it's the greatest game ever made (which it is) So you went in looking for flaws. Typical pessimistic attitude.
author: Richard

text:
+StellarSTLR1 ‚ÄúDick‚Äù Francis No no no, absolutely no! I did not look for flaws while playing the game. When I play a game I either like or dislike the game regardless of what other people think. And I do not think that Chrono Trigger is a bad game at all!

What i wrote and think is as subjective as it can get. I am not saying that the gameplay and the setting is bad, i am simply saying it is not my style. Nothing more nothing less.

text:
It's a little crazy, but if you're wearing headphones and you pay attention to the first instrument (the one that loops through the whole song), it sounds like it's spinning clockwise while making bell sounds on 3 (right), 6 (bottom), and 9 (left) and starting the loop again on 12 (top). Very fitting as it's like a clock and the song name is Corridors of TIME.

Maybe I'm overanalysing the song, but it makes me love it even more.

author: Owari Dragon

text: @Owari Dragon¬†2d Graphics, when done right, can be timeless. I think if younger people knew more about the snes classics, and had the patience to deal with emulators, games like Chrono trigger would still reasonably popular. It seems like a lot of newer games on steam get away with stale 2d sprite graphics and still become successful.(I sympathize with low budget indie developers, but it can get old) It makes me wonder how Chrono trigger would do if it was released as a new game on steam. ¬†
author: Norm Conel

text: @Norm Conel¬†Shovel knight is a good example
author: disklosr

text: @disklosr¬†I feel kind of guilty for liking shovel knight because I don't want to support overuse of the aesthetic , but it was made with intention of looking like an nes/snes game so I guess it's fine. It's very fun anyway.
author: Norm Conel

text:
Shovel Knight is amazing.
It's an hommage to classic 8-bit platformers like Megaman or Ducktales.
The music is great, the controls are tight, the characters and dialogues are charming.
Shovel Knight is already a masterpiece and one of the best games of this decade.
author: Owari Dragon

text: @Owari Dragon¬†I completely agree, but I think that some indie developers use pixle/sprite graphics as an easy way to make a bland game popular BECAUSE of the success of games that use the aesthetic masterfully. I think some newer games could benefit from a original art style, or simply and art style that is used so much that it loses its impact. Thats why I feel a little guilty. But thats not to say that games like Shovel Knight shouldn't use a retro/nes era art style because, like you said, it's an homage to 8-bit games of a past time and benefits greatly from the use of the art style.
author: Norm Conel

text: @Norm Conel No, most of the time it's because creating 3D graphics is a much bigger task to take on, hence the 2D/pixel art look. Some may be trying to go for that style on purpose like Shovel Knight but, most of these 2D indie games are just that, 2D because of the shear amount of extra work it takes to make a fully 3D game is exponentially higher & challenging. It's not a retro thing, they're just using there brains.

text:
If you add &hd=1 to the end of the url you get better sound, but video quality is the same. Pretty sure this works for a lot of videos listed as 240/360p, because years ago many videos that were 480p, and maybe 360p, became/were lowered to 240/360p. There may have also been videos that were originally 240p, but still had their audio quality lowered.

They seem to still be on YouTube's servers in their original quality, just not normally accessible without that extra bit of text at the end of the url. I found this out by trying it out one day a year or two ago, after realizing their were larger sizes available when I downloaded videos using KeepVid.

For example with this video what you normally see on Youtube is the one listed on KeepVid as 240p, and is 4.19MB in size. The one listed under "(Max 480p)" is 4.5MB in size. The video still appears to be of the same quality and 240p, but that extra 0.31MB seems to make a significant difference to the audio quality, allowing more depth of the music to come through. It's about a 6.9% difference in file size, and audio is usually significantly smaller than video, so this may be a large improvement one could expect in the sound on many videos.

My guess is that Youtube lowered the quality of many old videos years ago to save on bandwidth costs of people watching older videos that no longer provided them much profit, or something along those lines.

I realize &hd=1 is normally known for playing back videos at 720p, but it seems to work for setting videos to the highest quality they can be played at (other than 1080p or above) even if 720p is not available.

On this video I find listening to it without the &hd=1 added makes many of the sounds kind of dull/muffled/flat sounding. Hope this helps some people, enjoy.

text:
Square's doing it right so far. 
Chrono Trigger on Playstation and Chrono Trigger DS weren't remakes at all, because the game itself was left virtually untouched. The only real noteworthy changes were that Frog's speech wasn't as "old English" on the DS, and they added awesome cutscenes by Akira Toriyama (which could be turned off at the viewer's discretion).
Square only brought out ports of the game, re-releases if you may, because they know there's no need to change a winning formula.

author: TheMrRipleyz

text:
You do realise that there is a world of difference between a remake and a port? Obviously not, considering that you believe they're comparable.
I have no problem with ports, ports are always good. Unless something horrible goes wrong, they're the same game with the same feel on a different platform. 
A remake generally involves changing some of the core things that made us love the game in the first place. This obsession with things having to be updated and redone and "made better" is unhealthy.
author: TheMrRipleyz

text: He is arguing that Chrono Trigger should be left mostly as a port than remade with current technological capabilities as is being pushed for a lot of games nowadays. I also have to point out that your point that Chrono Trigger has been ported over to the PS3 and PSP contradicts your later point of deterioating hardware from being a large concern. Chrono Trigger does not face this problem as it can now be played in a pure ROM format. Also whining is not the same as complaining.

text:
When it came out, the strange hype that can surround a video games release turned out to be true!  Time-travel? Group attacks? Multiple endings?

It went from melodramatic to sweeping to heart-wrenching to world-ending, but is like no other rpg.  More dire and strategic than Secret of Mana, but more kinetic and gleaming than FF3. 

Truly a gem among Square's unbelievable successes.

author: Ehal256

text: I still remember my first experience with this game.  Back in 5th grade in 1995, my friend who had a lot of RPGs introduced me to incredible games like this and Secret of Mana.  He brought the instruction book to class and drew a picture of Frog.  He couldn't play games often so I borrowed it from him and a few years later when he stopped playing games I got it for $20!  Still the best deal I've gotten on a video game.
author: Satan's Taint

text: I agree.  It's a shame most people still don't realize that many video games are art.  I've been playing games like this for ages and my parents still don't realize that many old games had great music, art, story, and gameplay.  CT is a classic that will never be forgotten, and I love this song, still hear it in my head fairly often even thought it has been years since I've played the game and don't listen to game music on it's own much.
